Hongkong
Sept. 18, 1938
Mr. H. M. Bixby
Pan American Airways
New York, N. Y•
Dear Bix:
I have not written you for some time, partly because I have
felt that PAA rather frowned on personal letters, and also because
there has been little to say which has not been fully covered in my
letters to Mr. Morgan.
Your letter from Alaska was very much enjoyea
It certainty
must be
incoristing country up there ana from all I
have read about it it should nave considerable sound development.
Its contrast to China must have been refreshing•
am
sure you have been very much concerned over the latest
events out here in which the Japanese seemed to have declared open
season on all commercial planes.
It surely has caused me plenty of
head aches and
still
is.
You no doubt will have heard by the time this reaches you that
Kitsi is returning to the States on the Clipper on the 29th. These
recent developments certainly have upset our plans.
We had
planned
for her to go home the middle of this month and
get the baby and bring
him back at once, being back here by Christmas or much sooner. We
had taken an apartment on the Peak for six months from the middle
of November and I almost stafted believing in Santa Claus again.
With conditions as they
now are however it seems to me it would be
very unwise to carry out this plan so we are cancelling it completely.
We gave up the apartment and Kitsi is going home and will
stay there
until
general conditions are more satisfactory and the situation out
here is
safer. Neither of us is very happy over this but it is the
only solution.
The game out here is getting too rough and I do not
want her bere in Hongkong
in a ringside seat.
I have not idea how
it is going to work out or what is going to happen next but at least
I will
not
have to worry about her.
Also it seems quite evident
that I shall spend considerably less time in Hongkong in the future
than I have in the past so there is no point in her being here if
I cannot get here with reasonable regularity.
Kits has been a good
sport and a good soldier and it has been wonderful having her out
for this long but it is no place for her now. She would worry
herself sick.
Besides she will have been away from the baby for
seven months and that is long enough.
I do not want him to
not knowing either
one of us.
It has been a
grand
experience pop
Kitsi
and no doubt by the time she starts telling it to her grand
children it will have reached legendary proportions.
I feel very gARateful
to PAA for sending her out. No doubt when she gets back to the States
she will find some excuse for getting up to New York and will see you and
